repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
fix https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/23622

# Problem

Currently there is no distinction between executables in `$VIRTUAL_ENV` called `python.*` and Python interpreter excutables. For example in the following case (assuming `$VIRTUAL_ENV == '.venv'`)
```
.venv/python-argcomplete-check-easy-install-script
.venv/bin/python3.13
.venv/bin/python
```
the `.venv/python-argcomplete-check-easy-install-script` is evaluated as if it was another Python version,  triggering the error described in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/23622.

# Solution

Strict check on the executable name format.

comment_data.body: In case this attempt may be too restrictive, an alternative solution can remain inclusive at this level, and skip false-positive executables on later checks (`python_exepath()`).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -791,7 +791,7 @@ local function python()
   --- @param v string
   venv_bins = vim.tbl_filter(function(v)
     -- XXX: Remove irrelevant executables found in bin/.
-    return not v:match('python.*%-config')
+    return v:match('python[%-_%d%.]*$') or v:match('python[%-_%d%.]*.exe$')

comment_data.body: We also need to match `pynvim-python` since https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35273 . Is that relevant here?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -791,7 +791,7 @@ local function python()
   --- @param v string
   venv_bins = vim.tbl_filter(function(v)
     -- XXX: Remove irrelevant executables found in bin/.
-    return not v:match('python.*%-config')
+    return v:match('python[%-_%d%.]*$') or v:match('python[%-_%d%.]*.exe$')

comment_data.body: From what I understand --please correct if I'm wrong-- the point of this check is to evaluate the Python setup corresponding to the active virtual environment, together with the (safe) availability of `!python` in command mode. There is a separate check on Python integration (i.e. `pynvim`) preceeding the virtual env verification. Within the scope of this check, the `pynvim-python` command is also evaluated (as of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35273) While technically it is possible to have `pynvim-python` command installed within the current virtual environment, it does not have relevance for the virtual environment's standard Python setup. In this case the Python Provider check would take note of the `pynvim-python` command availability (and also highlight that the setup is "un-optimal"):
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -791,7 +791,7 @@ local function python()
   --- @param v string
   venv_bins = vim.tbl_filter(function(v)
     -- XXX: Remove irrelevant executables found in bin/.
-    return not v:match('python.*%-config')
+    return v:match('python[%-_%d%.]*$') or v:match('python[%-_%d%.]*.exe$')

comment_data.body: On the other hand I'm wondering to allow for `3.4.1a2` format as well? (https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/apiabiversion.html)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -791,7 +791,7 @@ local function python()
   --- @param v string
   venv_bins = vim.tbl_filter(function(v)
     -- XXX: Remove irrelevant executables found in bin/.
-    return not v:match('python.*%-config')
+    return v:match('python[%-_%d%.]*$') or v:match('python[%-_%d%.]*.exe$')

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  if invocation == '' or invocation == nil then
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -364,8 +364,14 @@ end
 
 -- Resolves Python executable path by invoking and checking `sys.executable`.
 local function python_exepath(invocation)
+  if invocation == "" or invocation == nil then

comment_regular_data.body:
> On the other hand I'm wondering to allow for `3.4.1a2` format as well? (https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/apiabiversion.html)

Probably. 

I don't get why https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/23622 is a problem. It's just a warning. The real check is to execute the python bin and try to run code with it. That is done elsewhere in the healthcheck, I think. 

So trying to come up with a perfect pattern for the name is not going to work. Filtering out false positives is good, and worthwhile, but the check should be much looser than what's currently in this PR.

The old `not v:match` approach is better, i.e. filter out known false-positives.

We know that `python-argcomplete*` is false positive, so just add that to the `not` match pattern (or add another one: `not v:match(...) and not v:match(...)`).

@justinmk Thx much for your response.

The issue is more than a warning. The `assert` in original code line `368` quits the healthcheck, preventing further evaluations.

I made an attempt to:
 - follow your advice and filter the false-positive
 - make sure that a warning may be raised in case, however not exiting execution

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(health): false positive causes entire python check to fail
